title: Sam Neill's from Dunedin and doesn't want you to buy Cadbury chocolate - ever again
text:
Sam Neill's from Dunedin and doesn't want you to buy Cadbury chocolate - ever again RACHEL CLAYTON Last updated 18:33, February 22 2017 Neil Mackenzie 
Sam Neill is asking all Kiwis and Australians to boycott Cadbury products. 
Kiwi actor Sam Neill has come out in support of Cadbury factory workers, asking people to never buy or sell Cadbury products again. 
In a Twitter post, Neill asked all New Zealanders and Australians to "NEVER sell or buy anything Cadbury EVER again" if Cadbury's owner, American food giant Mondelez International, follows through with the closure of its Dunedin factory. 
Neill also tweeted Dunedin was his home town and closing the Cadbury factory was, "ripping the guts out of a community and its history". if #Cadburys really close their factory in #Dunedin , I will ask every one here & Australia to NEVER sell or buy anything Cadbury EVER again — Sam Neill (@TwoPaddocks) February 21, 2017 
The iconic factory has been a landmark in New Zealand since opening as a biscuit factory in 1838. The announcement has come as a shock to many Kiwis, especially the 350 workers whose jobs are on the line. 
READ MORE: ​ * Mondelez's global $4 billion cost-cutting drive behind Dunedin Cadbury factory closure 
In a bid to stop Mondelez from shutting down the factory, Kiwis have started social media campaigns calling on people to boycott the corporation's products, which range from Kraft peanut butter to Moccona coffee. 
A " Boycott Cadbury NZ " Facebook page was set up in the wake of the announcement and has been liked almost 1000 times. And a change.org petition, " Cadbury reconsider closure of your Dunedin factory ", was started on Saturday and has almost 1000 signatures. #Dunedin my #Hometown . When #Kraft etc close factories like @Cadbury_NZ , they save, while ripping the guts out of a community & its history Ad Feedback 
Viviana Gage wrote: "I went to newworld (sic) today, and as I walked pass the chocolates, I imagine myself pulling off the shelves every single cadbury bar, and stomping on it as they lied on the floor..." 
Another Facebook user, Darryn Turner, wrote: "I love Cadbury but yeah it's for a good cause that we don't purchase." 
The boycott isn't likely to be more than a drop in the ocean for the food giant, which announced the factory closure as part of a $4 billion international cost-cutting drive. 
* Comments on this story are now closed. - Stuff
